Judging from the comments and likes:dislikes, I missed the mark with this video. 
I just want to make it clear that the failing was my own and not because of any brand talking points. They asked me what I wanted to talk about and I said 'how electric cars are the future.' They gave me total control over the script and video and didn't ask me to change a thing. Personally I didn't think this video was too branded because it's about electric cars in general. I drive an electric car and I like it a lot.

I see a lot of the comments concerned that I didn't talk about the negatives of electric cars. That's because this video is about why electric cars are the future, not 'why electric cars have some challenges to overcome'. Some people interpret the lack of negatives like I was only allowed to say positive things. That's not true.

Obviously in hindsight I should have talked about: 
Electric cars are still expensive - sure but as I noted battery costs are coming way down and they're cheaper to run

Electric cars produce more CO2 to manufacture than gas cars - but they compensate within 1-5 years by being more efficient and producing less to run

Lithium mining isn't great for the environment - true but no mining is great for the environment (it takes a lot to make any car) and we can recycle the batteries a lot more cheaply than going back to mining the raw material. New battery designs are also reducing the amount of rare metals required.

For long road trips you do need to take pit stops around charging stations.

If you're thinking about people charging at night, how does that affect the electricity grid? I personally think it's a good thing because it evens out demand, which is usually highest during the day.

Hydrogen fuel cell cars - this is just something I personally don't see happening because there's not enough existing infrastructure. Electricity is everywhere, easily charge at your house. Hydrogen is not. When I was graduating college in 2004 hydrogen fuel cell cars were meant to be right around the corner. They're still very fringe.

Rebuttal of the claim that "Electric cars are just better vehicles":
1: Very irrelevant metric, and there is clear evidence of that. Also: ICE cars have many gears giving them multiplication of torque. So many people don't understand the basics of automotive technology.
2: They have a lower centre of mass, which btw also raises the passenger position so when loaded up that decreases. But that lower centre of mass comes with the price of no or very low flexibility in placing that mass, horrible passenger comfort as the floor is raised and car manufacturers for some reason do not compensate for that lift by also lifting the seat height, forcing passengers to sit almost as if sitting on the floor! Terribly uncomfortable.
3: Hardly any electric cars have separate motors for separate wheels. Almost all of them are driven through a differential just like ICE cars. Also, ICE cars have limited slip diffs with electronic control which can do torque vectoring.
4: Electric cars are not quieter. Even very inexpensive cars like BMW's 1-series have incredibly quiet engines, let alone more expensive ones. You can't hear the engine. Auto Motor und Sport tested the whole BMW X3 range including the fully electric iX3, and the iX3 was NOT the quietest of them all. Also, for example BMW's i3 is incredibly much louder than the far cheaper 1-series even of the previous model generation.
5: At least in Europe that is not universally true, for sure soon not necessarily in the USA either. Actually due to cheap gas in the USA that's probably not true now either. Public charging is incredibly expensive compared to pure electricity cost in theory, they charge a lot for that. And you pay for those incredibly, astoundingly expensive chargers through your taxes. Last charger project I checked out in the USA had the official statement of costing taxpayers over $70.000 for one 40kW (so not even very fast) charger! For the home you need to have a charger installed and those costing, including installation thousands means that you'll fill up your ICE car with pretty much gas after keeping that money in stocks for a couple of years. And with the government forcing EVs upon us will skyrocket the demand for electricity and therefore the price will also skyrocket. 
EVs also consume a lot more than the manufacturers and blogger lie to you about their consumption. Especially if you live in a climate which has a winter your consumption can easily double or a lot more, and the costs go up with that. The reported consumption is not what you pay for in electricity, as they have dishonestly left out all the electricity they use in charging losses (reportedly around 10% minimum and can skyrocket especially in fast charging and if the battery is not at optimum temp), preconditioning the battery (=heating that massive lump of metal), preheating the cabin, and also heating the cabin while driving. They also leave out how if you stop, then the car gets cold again, no matter if you stopped for just one hour you'll still have to heat up the cabin again and the battery of course especially before charging... And heating up the cabin with electricity is horribly wasteful.
So no, you won't necessarily save at all compared to ICE and and pay more!
6: That is just purely wrong. Charging losses, keeping the battery at temp, preheating it for charging, heating the cabin with electricity = wasteful.
7: You can also fuel up a CNG car at home... And you can only charge a car at home if you have your own parking place or garage and you have paid for the installation of a charger.
8: Completely meaningless propaganda. All of the 6 last cars I've owned only need servicing every 2 years. And that one service every 2 years is no chore. All I have to do is go to the dealership and leave the keys and take their loaner car, or alternatively I have a coffee, read the papers and do some work in their waiting area for about 1,5 hours. That's every 2 years. And guess how often I have to take my EV to be serviced: also every 2 years! Less service items then of course, but a half hour service time difference every 2 years is meaningless. BTW PHEVs also have regenerative braking.
9: Absolutely false. EVs do contribute to climate change. Only in your extreme case of using your own solar panels to charge a very small-battery EV is there even a meaningful difference in CO2 emissions. First of all even solar panels cause CO2 emissions, and they are problematic waste. But as I said, that is the best case scenario, and in every EV scenario, especially with most EVs with big batteries the CO2 emissions in their production is horrific. Then their electricity production also causes CO2 and other pollution. Sometimes less, sometimes more, but the end difference is marginal compared to ICE cars, on average of course since there are so many variables. Due to the massive CO2 emissions in EV production they are worse for the environment compared to practically any and all ICE cars that are driven less than average amount of miles per year. Especially big battery EVs.
ICE cars on the other hand are not too bad compared to EVs even now, on average I'd estimate at worst only 20% more emissions (so absolutely not worth the trillions of cost coming from pushing the world into EVs), but above all they can be run on biofuels and e-fuels and then they are absolutely and completely cleaner than EVs. They absolutely kill the EVs on how low their emission are then. There are really many ICE cars running right now on biomethane, next gets biodiesel (NEXBTL) made from waste etc. which are in a completely different league in cleanliness compared to EVs. In many cases they can even be estimated to be NEGATIVE in greenhouse gas emission as they decrease methane emissions which is a multiple times stronger greenhouse gas than CO2. And e-fuels could be put into mass production for far less cost than a fraction of what is put into EVs in subsidies to bring us massively lower CO2 emissions than EVs.
10: Absolutely false. There is absolutely no basis on EVs being in any way different in safety features, sensors, or any 'self-driving' stuff. Totally ridiculous statement.

One other comment I would make is that the biggest problem to overcome at this point for electric cars has nothing to do with individual cars anymore. It's a problem of scaling. From what I've heard from various sources, there isn't even close to enough lithium mining available for the growth rate of electric cars even today, let alone what will be required to convert most of the world's vehicle supply to electric in the coming decade. Some sources suggest there isn't even enough lithium mining possible, on the entire planet.

I'd be interested in another video exploring that concept, with an in-depth look at how much lithium we think is available vs. how much we've tapped at this point. Of course if we can get space-based mining up and running lithium won't be a problem at all any longer, nor will basically any other rare material, but that's a long-term solution. In the short-term, to ramp production up from a few hundreds of thousands of cars per year to the hundreds of millions that will be required as all these companies introduce dozens of electric models to their fleets, how possible even is that?

There are those who say it's going to be a crippling delay in the adoption of electric vehicle technology, and may create an opportunity for the resurgence of hydrogen technology. That of course has its own problems, but unlike mining of a rare metal, which may not be able to ramp up quickly or at all, the biggest challenge for hydrogen—infrastructure—is a pretty simple problem: you can grow it as fast as you can throw money at it, since hydrogen is literally everywhere, and since it is a totally renewable resource, unlike lithium.

I'm absolutely pro electric cars, but "they dont produce any CO2 at all" is simply a lie. The electricity comes from somewhere, and that place produces CO2. If your country produces 50% energy from solar and 50% from coal, then roughly 50% of electric cars produce their energy through coal. And even if you went the extra mile and made sure you only use 100% green electricity, the process of produing green energy often is not entirely green, especially when taking the production of for example solar panels into account.
That said, obviously it's far superior and has the added benefit of becoming more CO2 efficient, as the grid itself improves.

If you charge your car with your own solar panels, that doesn't mean it's emission free. After all, the energy produced by the panels is now going to your car, and not something else which is now using fossil fuels to get its energy.

The autonomous cars which are "shared" sound good -- you need less cars. But paradoxically, that leads to more traffic. After the car dropped you off at home, and travels empty to the other side of town to pick the next person up, that's traffic that would not have been there if everyone had their own car. (And why pay $25 for a day of parking if your autonomous car can just drive endlessly around the block on cheap electricity?)

I'm sorry Veritasium, but I politely disagree. Electric has a lot of flaws, for which I will list a few:

Firstly, lithium batteries use cobalt electrodes, and the two places you can get cobalt on Earth are the DRC and Australia. The DRC has the majority of the reserves. And let's just say that the methods used aren't good for the health of the miners, and it poisons the land, and they use child labour.

Electric batteries effectively lose a lot of power in winter. It's to do with the temperature messing with the battery chemistry and the power used by the heater. At -6C, without the heater on the range typically falls by 12%, with it on it fell by 40%. Yes, that's right 40%. Now, with the way the climate is a little screwed up and some places are now regularly experiencing -35 to -40 in places like the northern US and Canada, that's going to take a lot of power for the heater and its going to reduce the range a hell of a lot. And let's not forget, a Tesla model 3 long range model has a range of 310 miles in ideal (25C) conditions, so at -6 you're down to 186 miles of range. It's ridiculous.

And there's the fact the batteries deteriorate. I use LiPos for model aircraft, which I really need because of the need for a high voltage for the high power motor. Endurance wise, a 'glow fuel' Or petrol IC can last a lot longer than I can, even when I fly economically. Anyway, I digress, the point is that the high discharge currents cause free lithium ions and break down the electrolyte, causing lithium oxide to build up on the electrodes and increase the internal resistance of the cell. Also, the cells begin to puff up with liberated O2 molecules from the electrolyte breaking down. Eventually, the cell needs to be decommissioned, because it can't deliver the power needed and because it is bloody dangerous and can explode if it gets too hot. Not a good idea. Same thing happens in mobiles and laptops, but at a slower rate because the power requirements are more reasonable than what's needed for a 4ft Corsair model. And so, it will happen to electric cars, and there's no way to get around it.
Note: lithium batteries also don't like being stored at full battery for long periods of time (long meaning more than a week). LiPos really don't like it. LiIon are more forgiving.

There's also the fact that resources are limited and cobalt has other uses, and there may not be enough.

So, how does the planet get around this? I say ditch electric and go for hydrogen IC. The exhaust is pure H2O, and you can make hydrogen by the electrolysis of water, so it's perfectly green.
Hydrogen fuel cells need platinum electrodes to catalyse the reaction. Platinum costs $27 per gram, not cheap. So, use internal combustion but switch the fuel to hydrogen. No precious metals needed.
Hydrogen IC would be green, provide reasonable efficiency and power, it's cold proof (unlike electric) and it would be reliable. Storage would be no different to if they were feeding it to a fuel cell, so no additional problem there.

- by the time the electric car leaves the factory already sooo much co2 has been used that a combustion car could have driven 100.000 km

I would say the biggest selling point of electric is the many varying paths to create electricity. Many alternate fuels use mechanical or thermal energy to create electricity then use that to create the fuel. Each cycle through which it passes is less efficient. Electrolytic reduction to create Hydrogen is one example. Ethanol is less energy dense and uses vast amounts of arable land simply for fuel.

The only partial rival in my opinion would be Carbon Monoxide which can be created using nothing but solar concentration and cobalt, (amongst other forms). This reduces atmospheric carbon and keeps us at a net zero/zero sum process. But even then, I would rather see the gas used to create electricity as solar concentration is not viable everywhere. Photo/thermo-voltaics as well as water and wind energy make it more available to more areas. In the end it's a tough guess. I suppose with the right data one could see how best to proceed. Transmission of electricity, even with AC is very wasteful on a national/global scale.
Transporting liquid carbon monoxide uses fuel and can be dangerous. Perhaps it would need to be doped with an odor as we do with propane.

Ultimately, it's easier for an individual to generate electricity than CO. CO could be more efficiently used to create electricity in a fuel station rather than used in a car where kinetic energy is oft lost. Perhaps both are options but in the end, the cars themselves will and should be electric. Pollution can be kept in concentrated factories which can then use recapture methods more effectively. We are on the verge of a fuel cell, (aka battery) revolution. Batteries can be replaced with pretty much any other batteries and a few circuits like voltage regulators to be made compatible. Much easier than retooling and engine and converting parts to new fuels which may be corrosive and have differing pressures, temps, etc. The reason the future is electric is because there are so many paths to get there and so many advancements coming which have ubiquitous use from cell phones to solar homes to laptops and watches and everything else. Cars can get lighter as battery tech improves.

The impact on the environment of electric vehicles, over conventional gasoline/diesel, has not been resolved in my mind. Unfortunately, your statement about their fuel source (electricity) having no impact on the environment is at best, misleading. The sun does not show every day, everywhere, requiring the vast majority of electric vehicles to use grid power to recharge. The world’s demand for electricity increases daily. It will continue to do so, especially as third world countries develop and come into the electronic age. Solar panels, windmills and all other current forms of “renewable” energy cannot even come close to keeping up with today’s power demand. It is unlikely they will tomorrow (if ever) as mankind’s thirst for electricity soars.
Just because your electric car is not creating any emissions while driving, does not mean it has no emissions. It just means the emissions are emitted at some distant power plant. Also, there are plenty of emissions associate with the mining, refining and manufacturing of billions of batteries needed for all of our battery-operated devices. The emissions are still there. They are just out of sight, out of mind.
I have a few unanswered questions regarding batteries for electric vehicles. Batteries are made from limited and rare resources. And while battery costs are coming down, to put a new battery in a Prius you’re looking north of $3000. That’s when the Prius goes to the scrap yard. Not because the car has reached the end of its life. But because the typical car owner does not plan for the expense. When faced with three Grand for a battery, the new vehicle typically wins out.
By the way, those solar energy panels you use to recharge your vehicle…also require batteries. Lots of very large, high capacity (and expensive) storage batteries. Plus, an inverter and some pretty expensive electronic control equipment, to operate properly. All of which requires frequent maintenance and periodic repair and replacement. Again, more batteries mean, more mining, more transportation of raw materials, more refining and more exploitation of the earth’s limited raw and rare elements.
Don’t get me wrong, I don’t hate electric cars. In fact, I agree with you, electricity will likely power vehicles of the future. However, the person driving today’s Prius who thinks they are doing their part to save the planet, may be living in a Fantasy Land. Is it possible, in fact, they are hurting the planet, more than they are helping? The jury is still out on this issue.
I don’t see the electric car of the future being one that uses a battery as its primary power source. A viable electric vehicle will need a power plant that can generate substantial electric energy for long periods of time. I’m talking days, weeks or months. With little, or no, “power up” time. Maybe, something like a fuel cell. Or, maybe some yet undiscovered, or unperfected, method of generating substantial electrical power on demand. Only the future will tell.
Until then, battery power cars will remain a very expensive and fancy “golf cart.” Good for short hops around the town and making their driver’s falsely feel good about themselves for saving the planet.

Here's the thing all electric car proponents should know - cost, need for infrastructure and manufacturing will delay this electric car future by a whole lot.


I don't live in the US, so here's what I can say. In my country, gas cars are several times cheaper than electric cars. As in, electric cars are a super luxury here right now. Gas car and other vehicles manufacturing is a huge source of jobs. Electric car manufactury seems to be overall adopting the massive replacement of jobs for automation. This is gonna have a big impact, perhaps not so much for countries where economies are not so dependant on this sector, but most definitely for countries that do, like mine.


Infrastructure proper to it like charging stations are still extremely paltry - to the point you cannot reliably make a trip with one. Not if you are going to smaller cities and expecting to charge your car in the way. Yes, you could use regular electricity from regular plugs, but not only those will charge way slower, most places here don't have a proper electric system that is adequate for stuff like charging cars.


Maintenance is yet another problem - they are far and few between and very expensive. The problem is having to import everything and needing specialized workers that are still in the minority. It is a new paradigm, so it'll take a while for people to adapt.


Finally, no, having to stop and wait for your car to be charged is a con in itself. Advertisements and pro electric car people need to step down their assumptions and their personal priviledged situations and understand that not every driver has the luxury of stopping in charging stations and wait for the batteries to charge. So, this is something for people to adapt to.


Further, let's add here: batteries have both an environmental cost, and a safety cost. Lithium is not an infinite resource, so it's a problematic factor. Even if modern battery technology allows for current electric cars to run for years on their original batteries, the fact is that at some point those will start failing, and become yet another source of toxic waste.


There is an obvious bias going on right now with electric car owners assuming that just because their daily routine is breezy and light enough to allow for these types of costs and cons don't affect too much their bottomline, that the same will be true for everyone else. It doesn't work like that.


Autonomous cars and the technology associated with it, even though isn't directly related with electric cars themselves, is poised to generate a whole ton of problems because of the way it's being made. First, it requires a whole ton of electronic circuitry and technology, which all have their own particular set of problems and particular industrial segmentation. Second, they are being made by technology monopolies that are highly interested in collecting your private data. Third, they are even more vulnerable to hacking and other computer related attacks in comparison to existing electronic systems of current gas cars. So, we're not only handing down the control and monitoring of cars to AIs, we are also handing it down to a very small set of tech monopolies.





Ok, now, with those in consideration. Electric cars have a way simpler construction overall. You are drawing power from batteries to drive a motor. This not only simplifies the overall build, and gives more control over things, but also reduces energy waste in general. So, it makes sense to go towards it. For gas, you need combustion chambers, the conversion of gas explosions to movement, the need to filter noxious gases and subproducts that results from this entire conversion, an extremely complex system to do all that, which weights a lot, heats a lot, wears down a lot, and needs constant replacement and repair of discardable parts. So yes, it is a more streamlined, elegant solution for cars.


The more we manage to source power from less complex and diversified sources, the easier it becomes to make it cleaner and simpler. For gas, you need transportation with ships and tank trucks, underground storages in gas stops, regulatory agencies and monitoring so this entire system isn't abused, among other stuff. Electricity goes through power lines. Ultimately, it'd be better if we had an incredibly robust eletricity generation and transmission system overall replacing both oil and gas as power sources, not only for cars, but for basically everything else.


Even though production of electricity, manufacturing of electric cars, and the battery production are all potential sources of pollution and toxic waste, gas cars are just simply worse overall. There are way more parts to break, way more disposable stuff going into trashcans, a pollution problem, noxious chemicals in several fronts, among other problems. With that, there's also the fact that gas cars haven't been significantly evolving for quite a while now. The tech is mature, and even some attempts to make them cleaner seems to be all fake and product of corrupted manufacturers alterating test results.


Now, for autonomy and use of tech, computers and AI. Unfortunately, humans have proven over and over and over again to be extremely bad drivers. The number of lives we lose every year because of drunk drivers or just plain incompetent drivers is staggering. The money and number of hours people spend on average during their lifetimes learning how to drive, fixing cars, and worrying about personal modes of transportation is just incalculable. There's definitely reason to worry about automating this entire aspect of peoples' lives, but I'd say we have to at least try considering the current costs.

Electric is great but we need significant improvements in battery tech. Solid-state batteries seem very promising. They should be much safer compared to current batteries using a liquid electrolyte as recent fires of parked as well as crashed Teslas have shown. Once the separator is pierced the chances of a thermal runaway happening increase greatly and very intense exothermic reaction, aka fire, is the the result. Also, while regular trips are not longer than 100 miles, not all people live in cities. Range anxiety is a real thing esp. when charging takes an hour or more. Energy costs are quite high in Germany in part because of only four large conglomerates owning and running the electrical grid though recent legislation now finally allows for individual home owner to own and operate as well as sell-back electricity produced using solar-panels on the roof. Another problem is that car companies really do not want to invest in new tech as it cuts into their bottom line. Dieselgate has shown this. The fact is that even solar power plants have an environmental footprint on a lifecycle basis. For instance, Concentrated Solar Power (CSP) has a footprint of 20 grams of carbon dioxide (CO2) per kilowatt-hour (kWh) of electricity produced, in addition to consuming vast amounts of water.

Similarly, photovoltaic (PV) power plants also have carbon footprints which, on a lifecycle basis can range from 12g per kWh for a facility using First Solar’s thin film modules, to as much as 24 g per kWh – for one using multi-crystalline silicon panels.

While the carbon footprint is of paramount importance in the context of decarbonising the energy system, other impacts created by the manufacturing of components of a PV system – such as acidification, eutrophication, abiotic resource consumption and particulate matter emissions – are also important.

The comparatively high carbon footprint of multi-crystalline silicon panels is a direct result of the energy-intensive processes required to refine silicon and ‘grow’ the ingots that are sliced into wafers. It is also a direct consequence of the fact that the manufacturing of commoditised multi-crystalline silicon panels had largely moved from markets where electricity has a low carbon intensity, to countries that often rely on coal and other carbon-intensive forms of electricity generation.
